page.title: 07LAND AND WATER.
page.content: The sparing use of insecticides allows a wide variety of wild flowers to grow. Some hedges remain and although elms have died out, broad-leaved trees and conifers abound. A variety of habitats houses a surprising range of wild life in Ockham, such as game birds, owls, roe deer and many rabbits - hares are scarce. Butterflies are increasing. Wild mallard nest by a stream and the RSPB has an observation post and boxes here. Kestrels are frequently seen eating birds killed on roads. Though fields are less cultivat -ed, parkland and horse-paddocks make a good environment for wildlife. The Wey Navigation has affected the area, controlling floods and encouraging ri- ver side life. Thames Conservancy slu- ice gates further control floods,here & on the Thames. Mosquitoes were a plague until cleared in the 1950's.
